channel.title: Open Source
channel.description:
Do you think open source for RSC private servers is a good thing or a bad thing?
[b]Pros[/b] You can allow people to develop the source code without worrying about it being leaked (it's pretty much impossible to develop big things without the full, running source code). It could entice more developers to get involved by being able to play around with the code.
[b]Cons[/b] Other servers could simply run the server and be competition, stealing years of hard work. It would make life for bot creators a lot easier. People could use the code to find exploits that otherwise wouldn't be known.
I like the idea and I'm completely with Peeter's thinking (and what he did with DarkQuest) but then the RSC scene lacks any real development anyway so what's the point? No one helped Peeter with DarkQuest so it all seems a bit pointless, especially when you consider that no-one even uses the source code today (everyone uses RSCAngel instead).
It seems like being a one-man-band is the way forward. What do you think?

item.dc:creator: @Peter Peeter
item.description:
@Peter wrote:

[quote author=Peeter link=topic=485471.msg3573539#msg3573539 date=1303242384]Thieving and agility are basically plugins that can be implemented a lot easierly in DQ then they’re implemented in RSCE/RSCA. The same goes with quests.

They’re already in RSCE though. That’s my point. Yes that can be ‘easierly’ implemented but by who? It requires work. All skills can be easily implemented into a bare source but it takes time and effort which most people aren’t prepared to put in. You put out a request for a Runecrafting plugin to be written and no-one contributed. What’s the point of having a plugin system if you have to write everything yourself anyway?

There’s also no point in mentioning client side modifications, as they have nothing to do with your servers source.

The client is arguably just as important as the server. RSCE’s client is so much nicer to use than RSCD’s, more features, sleeker, closer to RSC, more stable, etc.

As for the website modifications since you’re using the fluxbb forum software as your base it’s extremly hard to build anything new ontop of that (a pitfall most RSCD servers follow, including DQ/RSCA).

It does everything I need it to do. I haven’t felt any need to change or write an independent website. I don’t really get what you mean, if you include the forum from another directory you essentially can do whatever you want…

All in all you’re providing a ready to run setup that’s hard to maintain and extend.

Not really, I’m maintaining and extending it fine. People have put up with RSCD for years just fine. How much further do you need to extend anyway? It’s very unlikely any other server (other than RSCE) will ever see 300+ online again so it’s more than sufficient IMO.[/quote]

A new developer writes a new skill for you. This skill will be written into 17 different classes. After a month of running it on your live server you discover it has a crucial flaw and needs to be removed. You have to manually rip out the changes in 17 different classes to restore the core to it’s original state. In ripping out code from 17 classes you also accidentally ripped out a crucial bit of code that results in another bug.

A bunch of developers write 20 new skills for you. All of them require changes in 20 different classes. Each time a new skill or anything new is added your classes grow. At one point you have 20 classes with 10k lines in them.

This is what I’m talking about when I say hard to maintain.

item.dc:creator: @Evil1 Evil_
item.description:
@Evil1 wrote:

[quote author=Peeter link=topic=485471.msg3573186#msg3573186 date=1303212115]Then going OS is useless. The general idea is that everyone benefits from your code, not that you get n+1 new programmers.

That’s not what you argued before.

People would benefit from my code though; It undoubtedly better then RSCA which is considered to be the best released source.

Kryptix, I’d go open source if not only for the fact that people that would like to see how it works, but also for people that would like to jump in and help. Going open source means you can have far more people to look through the program and help find bugs/other problems and either commit their own fix or just tell you about it.

You’re right, it would be really nice but it would also go against me to, allowing people to run their own copy of RSCEmulation and essentially being competition in a matter of minutes. Plus, there’s always the malicous people that wouldn’t tell you and merely try and abuse anything they find.[/quote]Yea, that’s always the chance you have to take, but it happens with everything. I know people that take AbiWord’s source code, make a binary, and release it under a different name (under the same licensing though, of course); The fact is that your repository should still advance faster than anyone else that is trying to compete by using yours, especially if you get people to tag along and actually contribute. Although, after I found out about this guy doing the AbiWord thing, I did pretty much turn my back on open sourcing much, but in my opinion, a private server wouldn’t be too bad of a thing, unless you’re making a lot of money from it or something (I really don’t know, I’m hardly ever around these parts anymore lol)
